The complete works of Napoleon have
recently appeared at Paris, containing three
pieces written BY him at tho respective
ages of 90. 81, and 23, a selection of his re-
ports to the directory, during his campaigns
in Italy and Egypt; all his proclamations as
General In Chief. Consul and Emperor; the
history of the "Hundrcd Days." his opinions
on war, religion, the clergy, the nobility,
history. morality, the revolutions in France
and England; curious anecdotes, conhden-
tal letters and other productions.

We are requested to correct mistake
which occurred in the "Times,'' and some
other papers of New-York, in relation tothe
return OF the Hon. fleman Allen. late MIN
ister Of the United Slater to Chill. Mr.. a.
has not been re called, as therein stated; but
returns to the United States by his own par
ticular request, made to the Government
and granted. Those papers which have in
advertetlly committed this error IN phrasel-
opy will be doing Justice to the Minister by
correcting it.--.A. I. Com. .fdp.

OF the water works at Philadelphia" Now

ard Of orthodoxy in mechanical knowledge

The following anecdote of Commodore Rod
gers, is alike honorable to him as an individual,
and to the character of nation which he has SO
faithfully represented 1t is communicated to
us by "a friend of the Commodore, and in giving
it to our readers, we cordially unite with the
writer in his warm expressions of admiration of
the disinterested beneyolence which it records
OF that distinguished and accomplished officer.


Among many things calculated to excite in
terest on board the North Carolina, there is a
painting executed by one of the crew, edueat-
ed for an artist, which deveopes the peculiar
nhuInanity of the sangninary struggle subsistng
between the Turks and Greeks. 1t illustrates
an event which occurred when the ship lay at
Paros, and the painter has felicitousy repres Mt
ed the actual scene which took place on the
poop ofths vessel Two Greeks seized the ia
vorable opportunity of the ships being anchor
ed there, to bring on board, for sale, eight
Turkish female captves for whom they demand
ed three hundred and twenty dollars. The Com
modorc strongly reprobated practice so bar
barous, and urged the improperly of such a
wanton violation of the rules of all civilized ma
tions-at the same time offering fifty dollars for
the prisoners. Six of them were blacks, one of
a swarthy complexion, and one exceedingly fair
During the conference they were seated in
humble posture on the poop, and their looks
and actions evinced the intense interest they
felt in the result


The faircst, particularly exhibited symptoms
! he 'he ers raku Sad
to lberate them for the amount offered, insisted
that they were fairly their property by the rights
OF war, and declared their intention to take them
on board british trlgate laying near the North
Carolina, and sell them to the highest bidder
Com. Rodgers rather encouraged this movement,
in the hope that the British Commander might
be in a condition to give more for the prisoners
than himself, but had determined, however, if
the application should fail, to ransom them him.
self At any sacrifice, and when the Greek boat
left the ship he sent one Of his own to approach
the frigate on the opposite side to announce his
determination to the British Commander. Ap-
prehensve at the same time that violence would
be Offered to the females by the exasperated
Greeks in the event of their failing to sell them
to the Engl sh, he had prepared two of the ships
| bouts to pursue them the moment they should
leave the English ship for the shore, and bring
them to the North Carolina.


As tie Greek boat approached the frigate one
Of then countymen, pilot on board her, dcs-
cried her from the forccasie, and pcrenptorlly
and insutin9ly directed them to keep oft. They
then made all speed for the shore, where they
told the interpreter ofthe North CarOhna, that
they would cut The hroats Of Mctr prismle,S.--
| The boats Of the North Carolina overlook them
ten miles from the ship and brought them on
board, when the Commodore, as an additional
nducemcnt for them to comply with his propo-
sition, declared thai he had doubts of their right
to sell them; and that if they persisted III rctus
ing his terms, he should feel obliged TO detan
them, and send sloop of war to Napoli di Ro-
mania to ascertain their right to dispose ofthem.
After some hesitation, they consented to release
them to the Commodore for the fifty dollarsi
and they were afterwards comfortably clothed
by subscription for which, and all other atten-
ton shown them, they evnced the iyellest graf
itude.


They were subsequently restored to their
/ freedom among their countrymen in Smyrna
expressing desire to go the United States, from
the fact that their degradation by capture and
exposure to the Greeks, and particularly by
their having been thrown into the possession OF
infdcls, would irrctrievably prevent their recov-
eiing tle original rank in society i'll their own
conntry They had been carried to several
islands for sale previously to their beng purchas-
ed on board the North Carolina, and TINS dlsap-
pontment tended to aggravatc the unsubducd
fcrocity Of the Greeks.


Bv this act of disinterested bencyolence, Com
modore Rodgers rescued these helpless and un-
offending females, devoted with all probability,
10 a cruel death; and the hope is indulged that
this distinguished example will be followed BY
every American officer placed i'll similar circum-
stances. To avoid a compromittal OF our neu-
trality is the strict obligation ofeyery officer, but
it is equally imperative upon hin, to mitigate,
whenever lie can do so without positive viola
ton of duty, the calarnitics Of war.

A professional gentleman, at the age OF
twenty-threc married, and insured his life
fer g50o0, for which he paid @lo5 annually.
Though his practice was extensive, yet his
expenditure in consequence o! his having 6
children to maintain and educate, lett him
unable to realize any property; and at his
death, (Which occurred at the age OF fltty)
his only property vas this policy, then worth
97000, increased by the bonuses or profits
of the Society," which enabled him to give to
his children $1,000 each, and to his widow
I10oo which procured for her an annuity
of hundred pounds a year during her life
There is not any class in community or Sit
uation in society, in which life-insurance
may not be made conducive to the happi-

We understand that Mr. James Colburn,
Of Dracut, has inYented a composition which
renders Shingles ncombustblc and much
more durable. Many buildings in his neigh
borhood have already been covered with
them. The price OF the composition and
nuttinr on is only nine cents yard; and the
SHINGLES have fine slate color.-Bos. Pal

The Philadelphia United States Gazette
ne Monday. savs:-..it is stated that the
whole rang of rogues which for some time
mast have been engaged in making and pass
ing counterfeit notes OF the United otates
Rank Of the denomination of twenty and one
hundred dollars, have been arrested, alter
long and careful search, by the ponce OF the
city. The bank will hereafter issue the
notes of one hundred dollars and twenty dol
lars on new plate"

we publish to- day, under our foreign head,
a very interesting document furnished BY a
late arrival from Europe, purportins to be
treaty concluded upon between Engiand'
France, and Russia, "for the settlement OF
Greece" The Interference OF these powers
with view to put an end to the sangunaiy
strife between Turkey and Greece, has been
for some time looked for; and We had reason 20
expect, from Christian powers, an interference
which should reflect honor upon themselves,
, and be a benefit to the cause OF Christianity
but, upon pcrusal OF the proposed treaty,
the reader will perceive that the Greeks, at
Ter desperate struggle for about six years,
during which they have suffered all the mise
ries and privations that war ever entallcd up
on nation, are at last to submit TO tle VI
toman yoke, and acknowledge urkiSh
ruler. For more .han three years the en-
e,pics of Greece have been strengthened
Nv the contributions of the humane Trough


out Europe and America, whose generous
svmpatbies for their sufierings induced them
to give largely for the relief OF those VINO


were diving with hunger, and to stfensshen
the feeble exeltions OF the army to regain ina.
liberty which they had once lost and the SOIL
| of their forcGathcrs which they had been dilv-
en- from by their mcrciless invaders'-And at
time when We expected to sec the Christian
powers of Europe step in and vindicate the
rights Of the oppressed by acknowledging
their independence, we behold them advocat-


ing the cause of the oppressor, and deereemg
flat the Greeks shall acknowledge Turk
ish ruler and pay tribute to the lniidel Prmcc,
We heartily wish that the proposed treaty


may be rejected with disdain, and that Greece
NAV hold ,ut until Turkey shall be compelled,
by the sword, to accede to terms which Will
guarantee to them justice as apeoplc and iib-
erty as nation,

.qccideaf. We noticed an accident few days
ago, by which young man had ms leg 'aken non, OIL
Ife vas on board of a sloop, near the windass,
Willie she was nearing the wharf, and his leg was
caught between the wndlass and the bite ofthe tl
rone. and took it clean off below the knee. The
thing was done in an instant, and the young man
was SO astonished that he neither spoke nor
groaped. nor moved muscle of his face. A ply
sici.n made an artificial tourniquet with rope
and splintcrs, and he was placed unconplaining
in m Carriage. person ran after the carriage.
bearing the fractured limb, which he handed
through the window to the sufferer ieg, boot boot
and psntaloon, and he placed it ON his lap very.
cooliy. 1t was altogether rare exhibition OF
stoical Indifference under such shocking ca
lamity. We learn, says the Enquirer that he is
doing well.

A new carriage has been invented at Par
is, which it is exceedingly difficult to over
turn. When any Que of the wheels meets
with an obstacle, it is raised up by itself,
and the body of the carriage remains firmly
ON the three remaining wheels. The inven-
tor (whose name is Van-Hoorek,) has OBJ
tanned patent for this useful inyention,y

A very difficult surgical operation was
performed at Eastport few weeks since


the reduction of a iurated hH joint, occa-
stoned by the falling of barn frame. The
Eastport Sentinel gives the annexed account
of the operation The bone had been out
of place forty-three days, and the patient,
Mr.. Loring, of Perry, young man % years
of age, was extremely reduced by long and
painful suffering. 1t was exactly one OF
those cases described by Sir Ashley Cooper
as being dislocation into the ischiatic moth,
the head of the thigh bone being easily telt
back and little above the socket-the limb
was about 4 of an inch shorter than the 9TH

err The operation was conducted by DR..
Hawks, assisted by DR.. Aver; and reduction
was completely effected, and without the
aid of pullies, in from IS to 90 minutes
This is the sixth case of luxatcd hip Dr.
Hawks has succeeded in reducing.

.,In case the Ottoman Porte does not ac-
,ent within the space of one month, the
mediations which shall be proposed, the
heh contracting parties agree upon the toi-
lowing measures


+ Ii shall be declared by their represent
,t;ycs at Constantlnople to the Porte, that
,he Inconvenience and evils pointed out IN
,he public treaty as inscparablt IRON the
sate of things subssting in the East Tor the
ID SIX wears, and the termination OF which
mroueb the means at the disposal OF the sub
lime Porte. appears still remote, impose up
on the high contracting parties the necessi-
~ oftaklng immediate measures iof an APP
nroximation with the Greeks


II is to be understood that this approxim-
,,ion shall be brought about by establishing
commercial relations with the Greeks, by
sending to them for that purpose, and re.
eciyinc from them consular agents, so long
as there shall exist among them authorities
capable of maintaining such relations


III. Ifwithn the said term OF one month.
,be Porte do not accept the armsticc pro-
1osed in the first article of the public Urea
n. or if the Greeks refused to execute i,
the high contracting powers shall declare 70
that one of the two c0ntenting parties which
shdii WISH 10 CONTINUE uNslifitlNo VI ~ 'S'Etti
Il such become necessary, that the said hlsh
contracting powers intend to exert all the
means which circumstances may suggest 70
their prudence 10 obtain the Immediate et-
feet Of the armistice, the execution ot which
they desire, by preventing, in as tar as may
be in their power, all collision. between the
contendlng parties, and i'll fact, immediate
" after the aforesaid declaration, the high
contracting powers will conformity employ
all their means in the object thereof, with
out, however, takinm any part in the hostil-
ities between the two contendng parties.


In consequence the high contracting pow
ers will Immediately after the signature OF
the present additional and secret article,
transmit eventual Instructions conformable
to the provisions above set forth, to the ad,
mirals commanding their squadrons in the
seas of the Lcvant.


III Finally, if, contrary to all cxpccta-
tlons, the measures do not yet suffice to in
duce the adoption by the Ottoman Porte OF
the propositions made by the high contract
ing parties, or if, on the other hand, the
Greeks rcnounce the conditions stipulated
in their favor in the treaty of this day, the
high contracting powers will nevertheless,
continue to prosecute the work of paCihca-
tion on the bases agreed upon between them;
and, in consequence. they authorize from
this time forward their representatives. in
London to discuss to which. it may become
necessary to resort


The present additional and secret article
shall have the same t,rce and value as it II
had been inserted, word for word, in the
treaty of this day Il shall be ratified, and
| the ratification thereof shall he exchanged
at the same time as those Of tile said treaty
In faith whereof, the respective pleupo-
tentiaries have signed i, and have thereto
affixed the seals Of their arms.


Done at London, this 9th Of July, in II,
wear of Grace 1927

II viii be seen ~ our paper, to-day that we
have introduced into its columns hohtical
hcaa; under whicl. we propose to give weekly
a cwalticles, relative to thcpresidcntial ques-
ton; such as the results of Elections in the Sc
vcral states, interesting letters, and other doc
unrnts, throwing light upon the merits and
dement's Of public men, &c. Tic question
may be asked, how \ thiss why do you Dc
part from your neutral course We hall an
swer bv sayng---thc public, and particularly
our au5@fibrtS, prTAND that We should do
il sand being alive to our own interest, as eve
~ niah should be, We tttvc thought proper 70
comply We shall no. however, strictly speak
ing, depart from oal neutral course Such ar
ticles as MAY be Inserted, relative to the pres
ilcntal question, shall appear without COM
mcnt neither shall any partakc Of that abu-
siye character 50 much III vogue at present.
We shall publish for the qualification Of our

lcctons shall be, as far as NC are able TO make

more in tAlo our Of one candidate than OF the O.
tlci'


The time has arrived when public c%cite-
mcnt calls loudly for information upon tAe
great question now before the people. nc
mercury of party feeling points the tcmpcra-
ture Of the political atmosphere At .feper hfat;
and for the Wilmingtonian to keep herjectly
coLp at such timc is a thing out of the ques-
tion--It must part;,ke a fttie of the nature OF
the times, TO exist. But while VIC open our
paper to clear, temperate, and candid dis-
cussion Of the matter, let it be explicitly un-
derstood, that we take no part in tive WI
not appear in the listsas the avo~c'l champion
Of either party

The complete works of Napoleon have
recently appeared at Paris, containing three
pieces written BY him at tho respective
ages of 90. 81, and 23, a selection of his re-
ports to the directory, during his campaigns
in Italy and Egypt; all his proclamations as
General In Chief. Consul and Emperor; the
history of the "Hundrcd Days." his opinions
on war, religion, the clergy, the nobility,
history. morality, the revolutions in France
and England; curious anecdotes, conhden-
tal letters and other productions.

We are requested to correct mistake
which occurred in the "Times,'' and some
other papers of New-York, in relation tothe
return OF the Hon. fleman Allen. late MIN
ister Of the United Slater to Chill. Mr.. a.
has not been re called, as therein stated; but
returns to the United States by his own par
ticular request, made to the Government
and granted. Those papers which have in
advertetlly committed this error IN phrasel-
opy will be doing Justice to the Minister by
correcting it.--.A. I. Com. .fdp.

proper source for information, or perhaps, ne
yer gone beyond the limits of their own
Board, and gives as an example Of their weak
ness "that majority ofthe Committee were
persuaded to believe that there was no valve
between the forcing pump and the reservoir
OF the water works at Philadelphia" Now
whatever the Committee may have been


persuaded to believe" shall not undertake
to determine; but at the same time | make
no hesitation in saying that in that opinion they
were entirely correct.s In the pumps at Fair
Mount water works there is no OaiUe between
the etluction valves Of the pump (for they are
aeuble)and the stop water on the end Of the
pipe in the reservoir. For this have the
most unquestionable authority. In making
this statement know shall forfeit all claim
to common sense in the opinion of this stand
ard Of orthodoxy in mechanical knowledge
and in this case only ask my fellow w-citizens to
inquire into the fact and Judge between u.s.


If our friend O. would take little more
pains to get correct information, his commu-
nications would have been of a very different
character from what they have been,
and perhaps no person would have taken the
trouble to investigate his motives for writing
them. He has, however, no right to complain
that this has been done; for when a man APP
pears ncognto making direct and SPECIFIC
charges against Individuals, he ought to cN-
pcct that some one would take the pains to IN
vcstigate his name and character. SolonS as
he thought himself i'll the dark there was no
impropricty in making his own garbet state
ments, and endeavoring to convince the pub
lie that the Watering Committee was COM
posed Of imbaciity itself. 1t was then no per
sonal allu,ion, for the Committc consists OF
four or five persons and il was not applied to
any njp Of theu,--to state that they were per-
vclllr a Mechanical Power for which it IS
acknowledged on all hands thcy paid very
high price. There was then no improprlcty
on informing the public that the plans OF the
committee were very njudicipnsly laid, and
that a very gre i and useless expenditure q
tho public money would be the consequence
II he hal in the first place informed the Com
n;ttce that it would be on object to SAKE the
{ricfi50 occasioncd BY forcing the water tiro
the main pipe until II Lad gained perpeh
die,ll4r ascent Of about IS feet, or level with
the head he might hase received such ihtpr-
nation as wcu,d have prevented the nccrsai-
" Of public investigation.


Pit this would not do, lie was oycrhowins
with knowledge and with wrath. And i must
be poured out, the one on the public and the
other on the Committee, the former have re-
ccived their full share, considering il was graz
tuitous, and the latter have no doubt been
taught better than ever again to negative the
respectful petition Of a man Of his consummate
wisdom. r.
| rtIfwe understand the subject of our Cores


poudents, "p." and O." we believe the form
er is under some mistake. The ednction
yaires are those alluded to bvQ. which sever


al Of the Committee were induced to believe
! had been dispensed with; for these are be


tween the forcing punl, and the reservoir


Ed

err. The operation was conducted by DR..
Hawks, assisted by DIR. Aver; and reduction
was completely effected, and without the
aid of pulies, in from IS to 90 minutes
This is the sixth case of luxatcd hip Dr.
Hawks has succeeded in reducing.


The following anecdote of Commodore Rod
gers, is alike honorable to him as an individual,
and to the character of nation which he has SO
faithfully represented 1t is communicated to
us by "a friend of the Commodore, and in giving
it to our readers, we cordially unite with the
writer in his warm expressions of admiration of
the disinterested beneyolence which it records
OF that distinguished and accomplished officer.


Among many things calculated to excite in
terest on board the North Carolina, there is a
painting executed by one of the crew, edueat-
ed for an artist, which deveopes the peculiar
nhuInanity of the sangninary struggle subsistng
between the Turks and Greeks. 1t illustrates
an event which occurred when the ship lay at
Paros, and the painter has felicitousy repres Mt
ed the actual scene which took place on the
poop ofths vessel Two Greeks seized the ia
vorable opportunity of the ships being anchor
ed there, to bring on board, for sale, eight
Turkish female captves for whom they demand
ed three hundred and twenty dollars. The Com
modorc strongly reprobated practice so bar
barous, and urged the improperly of such a
wanton violation of the rules of all civilized ma
tions-at the same time offering fifty dollars for
the prisoners. Six of them were blacks, one of
a swarthy complexion, and one exceedingly fair
During the conference they were seated in
humble posture on the poop, and their looks
and actions evinced the intense interest they
felt in the result


The faircst, particularly exhibited symptoms
! he 'he ers raku Sad
to lberate them for the amount offered, insisted
that they were fairly their property by the rights
OF war, and declared their intention to take them
on board british trlgate laying near the North
Carolina, and sell them to the highest bidder
Com. Rodgers rather encouraged this movement,
in the hope that the British Commander might
be in a condition to give more for the prisoners
than himself, but had determined, however, if
the application should fail, to ransom them him.
self At any sacrifice, and when the Greek boat
left the ship he sent one Of his own to approach
the frigate on the opposite side to announce his
determination to the British Commander. Ap-
prehensve at the same time that violence would
be Offered to the females by the exasperated
Greeks in the event of their failing to sell them
to the Engl sh, he had prepared two of the ships
| bouts to pursue them the moment they should
leave the English ship for the shore, and bring
them to the North Carolina.


As tie Greek boat approached the frigate one
Of then countymen, pilot on board her, dcs-
cried her from the forccasie, and pcrenptorlly
and insutin9ly directed them to keep oft. They
then made all speed for the shore, where they
told the interpreter ofthe North CarOhna, that
they would cut The hroats Of Mctr prismle,S.--
| The boats Of the North Carolina overlook them
ten miles from the ship and brought them on
board, when the Commodore, as an additional
nducemcnt for them to comply with his propo-
sition, declared thai he had doubts of their right
to sell them; and that if they persisted III rctus
ing his terms, he should feel obliged TO detan
them, and send sloop of war to Napoli di Ro-
mania to ascertain their right to dispose ofthem.
After some hesitation, they consented to release
them to the Commodore for the fifty dollarsi
and they were afterwards comfortably clothed
by subscription for which, and all other atten-
ton shown them, they evnced the iyellest graf
itude.


They were subsequently restored to their
/ freedom among their countrymen in Smyrna
expressing desire to go the United States, from
the fact that their degradation by capture and
exposure to the Greeks, and particularly by
their having been thrown into the possession OF
infdcls, would irrctrievably prevent their recov-
eiing tle original rank in society i'll their own
conntry They had been carried to several
islands for sale previously to their beng purchas-
ed on board the North Carolina, and TINS dlsap-
pontment tended to aggravatc the unsubducd
fcrocity Of the Greeks.


Bv this act of disinterested bencyolence, Com
modore Rodgers rescued these helpless and un-
offending females, devoted with all probability,
10 a cruel death; and the hope is indulged that
this distinguished example will be followed BY
every American officer placed i'll similar circum-
stances. To avoid a compromittal OF our neu-
trality is the strict obligation ofeyery officer, but
it is equally imperative upon hin, to mitigate,
whenever lie can do so without positive viola
ton of duty, the calarnitics Of war.


[NmJoM Herald


A professional gentleman, at the age OF
twenty-threc married, and insured his life
fer g50o0, for which he paid @lo5 annually.
Though his practice was extensive, yet his
expenditure in consequence o! his having 6
children to maintain and educate, lett him
unable to realize any property; and at his
death, (Which occurred at the age OF fltty)
his only property vas this policy, then worth
97000, increased by the bonuses or profits
of the Society," which enabled him to give to
his children $1,000 each, and to his widow
I10oo which procured for her an annuity
of hundred pounds a year during her life
There is not any class in community or Sit
uation in society, in which life-insurance
may not be made conducive to the happi-

We understand that Mr. James Colburn,
Of Dracut, has inYented a composition which
renders Shingles ncombustblc and much

borhood have already been covered with

The Philadelphia United States Gazette
ne Monday. savs:-..it is stated that the
whole rang of rogues which for some time
mast have been engaged in making and pass
ing counterfeit notes OF the United otates
Rank Of the denomination of twenty and one
hundred dollars, have been arrested, alter
long and careful search, by the ponce OF the
city. The bank will hereafter issue the
notes of one hundred dollars and twenty dol
lars on new plate"

we publish to- day, under our foreign head,
a very interesting document furnished BY a
late arrival from Europe, purportins to be
treaty concluded upon between Engiand'
France, and Russia, "for the settlement OF
Greece" The Interference OF these powers
with view to put an end to the sangunaiy
strife between Turkey and Greece, has been
for some time looked for; and We had reason 20
expect, from Christian powers, an interference
which should reflect honor upon themselves,
, and be a benefit to the cause OF Christianity
but, upon pcrusal OF the proposed treaty,
the reader will perceive that the Greeks, at
Ter desperate struggle for about six years,
during which they have suffered all the mise
ries and privations that war ever entallcd up
on nation, are at last to submit TO tle VI
toman yoke, and acknowledge urkiSh
ruler. For more .han three years the en-
e,pics of Greece have been strengthened
Nv the contributions of the humane Trough


out Europe and America, whose generous
svmpatbies for their sufierings induced them
to give largely for the relief OF those VINO


were diving with hunger, and to stfensshen
the feeble exeltions OF the army to regain ina.
liberty which they had once lost and the SOIL
| of their forcGathcrs which they had been dilv-
en- from by their mcrciless invaders'-And at
time when We expected to sec the Christian
powers of Europe step in and vindicate the
rights Of the oppressed by acknowledging
their independence, we behold them advocat-


ing the cause of the oppressor, and deereemg
flat the Greeks shall acknowledge Turk
ish ruler and pay tribute to the lniidel Prmcc,
We heartily wish that the proposed treaty


may be rejected with disdain, and that Greece
NAV hold ,ut until Turkey shall be compelled,
by the sword, to accede to terms which Will
guarantee to them justice as apeoplc and iib-
erty as nation,

.qccideaf. We noticed an accident few days
ago, by which young man had ms leg 'aken non, OIL
Ife vas on board of a sloop, near the windass,
Willie she was nearing the wharf, and his leg was
caught between the wndlass and the bite ofthe tl
rone. and took it clean off below the knee. The
thing was done in an instant, and the young man
was SO astonished that he neither spoke nor
groaped. nor moved muscle of his face. A ply
sici.n made an artificial tourniquet with rope
and splintcrs, and he was placed unconplaining
in m Carriage. person ran after the carriage.
bearing the fractured limb, which he handed
through the window to the sufferer ieg, boot boot
and psntaloon, and he placed it ON his lap very.
cooliy. 1t was altogether rare exhibition OF
stoical Indifference under such shocking ca
lamity. We learn, says the Enquirer that he is
doing well.

A new carriage has been invented at Par
is, which it is exceedingly difficult to over
turn. When any Que of the wheels meets
with an obstacle, it is raised up by itself,

the reduction of a iurated hH joint, occa-

of the operation The bone had been out
of place forty-three days, and the patient,
Mr.. Loring, of Perry, young man % years
of age, was extremely reduced by long and
painful suffering. 1t was exactly one OF

was about 4 of an inch shorter than the 9TH

Hawks, assisted by DR.. Aver; and reduction
was completely effected, and without the
aid of pullies, in from IS to 90 minutes
This is the sixth case of luxatcd hip Dr.
